As a Project Management minor, you will learn foundational project management skills applicable to a wide array of industries through specific courses such as Project Management Process, Leading Projects, Project Planning, Managing Project Risk, and Project Control.

Embry-Riddle’s Minor in Propulsion provides students with a fundamental understanding of both airbreathing and rocket propulsion. The minor provides a background in propulsion for students in various disciplines, including aerospace engineering, mechanical engineering, space physics and others. This minor will help prepare you for a career in the aerospace industry, working on gas turbine engines, rockets, missiles and more.

At Embry-Riddle, a Psychology minor can provide students from all degree programs with an understanding of human behavior in a variety of contexts, which can lead to better professional performance and a more fulfilling life. The minor expands students' understanding of the human mind, including theories of cognition, personality, and social psychology. These concepts are taught through a diverse curriculum covering topics such as abnormal psychology, forensic psychology, and human factors. Psychology coursework can help students develop practical skills applicable to careers in the military, criminal justice, law, business, and education. Students will also gain valuable experience working with data, learning about research, and developing critical thinking skills related to various real-world situations and career fields.

The Research Foundations minor is designed to provide students with foundational knowledge and skills in research methodologies and practices. Students will learn about research ethics, data collection and analysis, scientific writing, and presentation skills. The minor is suitable for students from any discipline who wish to enhance their research capabilities or prepare for graduate studies. This minor provides a strong foundation for future research endeavors in academic or professional settings.

The Robotic Systems Minor at Embry-Riddle's Daytona Beach campus gives students from various majors the opportunity to broaden their skills and knowledge in the growing field of robotics. This minor offers a flexible option to complement a student’s primary area of study and enrich their education by studying robotic systems from a multidisciplinary perspective. The curriculum focuses on an applied, hands-on approach to designing, building, and programming robotic systems. Robotic Systems is a burgeoning field that will impact industries across the globe. Adding a minor in robotic systems to your degree program will enhance your skillset for a variety of occupations, from aerospace to computer science, from engineering to mechanical science. This program can prepare students to: Design, build, and program autonomous robotic systems. Integrate multiple sensors and communication devices into robotic systems. Understand the theory behind robotics while also applying a hands-on approach. Apply problem-solving skills to real-world applications. Analyze and debug robotic systems.

Requirements: The minor in robotics is intended for engineering and computer science students to provide them with the knowledge and skills necessary to be successful in the field of robotics and automation. Students from other degree programs are encouraged to consult with the minor coordinator about their eligibility.
Description: Enhance your skills with an interdisciplinary minor focused on the fundamentals of robotics, including autonomous intelligent systems and robotic systems design. Course work in this minor develops students’ expertise in the foundational mathematics, physics, computing and design principles relevant to modern robotics. This minor is open to all students, but is particularly suitable for engineering and computer science majors. Contact the Department of Mechanical Engineering for more information.

Requirements:
Students must complete 15 credit hours of Russian Studies courses.

Required Courses
RS 101 Elementary Russian I
RS 102 Elementary Russian II
RS 201 Intermediate Russian I
RS 202 Intermediate Russian II
RS 301 Advanced Russian I

Prerequisites may apply.

Students may choose to take a language placement exam administered by the Department of Humanities and Communication in order to waive any of the listed required courses. Students will choose from the list of electives below to meet the 15 credit hour minimum for the minor.
Description: The Russian Studies Minor program is designed for students with an interest in Russian language and culture. Students can complete the program with no prior Russian language experience. Completion of this minor provides students with a foundational understanding of the Russian language as well as Russian literature, history, and culture. Graduates of the program will have a competitive edge for careers in government, intelligence, international relations, and STEM professions requiring a strong understanding of Russian language and culture. The minor requires a minimum of 15 credits including at least 9 credits at the 300-level or above. Students must maintain a minimum 2.0 GPA in the courses that apply toward the minor. Up to 6 credits may be transferred from another institution toward the minor, subject to approval.

Embry-Riddle’s Science Literacy minor provides students with the critical thinking skills needed to interpret and evaluate scientific claims and the communication skills to articulate scientific information to both expert and lay audiences. Students will also be able to recognize the impact of scientific issues on society. This interdisciplinary minor builds on the sciences and humanities, preparing students to critically evaluate a wide range of scientific topics encountered in their daily lives, including climate change, public health, and artificial intelligence. The minor also helps students communicate scientific data and theories in an ethical and effective manner, equipping them to translate complex scientific information for public understanding across diverse media platforms.

ScholarshipAmount: Up to S$12,000 (Co-payment Grant), S$5,000 (Honors Scholarship), S$500 (Referral Grant)
ScholarshipType: Co-payment Grant, Alumni Grant, Referral Grant, Honors Scholarship

ProgramName: Minor in Small Uncrewed Aircraft Systems (sUAS) Operation
Description: The Small Uncrewed Aircraft Systems (sUAS) Operation minor introduces students to the basic aspects of Uncrewed Aircraft Systems (UAS), specifically small uncrewed aircraft (sUA). This minor offers a blend of theoretical knowledge and practical application, providing students with the skills and knowledge necessary to pursue employment in the sUAS industry or to incorporate sUAS operations into their existing profession. The curriculum includes courses that cover UAS regulations, operations, applications, and hands-on flight experience, ensuring graduates are well-versed in both the technical and operational aspects of sUAS.

Requirements: The Minor in Space Operations is available to all degree-seeking students at the Daytona Beach campus.
Description:
Students will gain an understanding of how space systems are designed, operated, and integrated into complex space missions. Graduates will be prepared to contribute to the operation of spacecraft, ground systems, and space-related activities in both government and commercial sectors. This minor provides students with knowledge, skills, and abilities for a career in the space industry focusing on operations.

The Space Operations minor requires 15 credit hours of coursework covering orbital mechanics, spacecraft systems, space mission operations, and space policy and law. Students will learn about the current state of the space industry, its challenges, and opportunities. The minor also provides hands-on experience with space mission design and simulation tools.

The Minor in Space Physics is an excellent option for students pursuing a degree in a related field who want to broaden their knowledge with an understanding of space physics. Space Physics deals with the study of plasma processes occurring in the space environment, particularly in the Earth’s magnetosphere, ionosphere, and the sun’s corona. Space physics is an emerging field with many opportunities for graduates, especially in space weather, where space events affect technological systems on Earth and in space.

ProgramName: Minor in Space Policy, History and Culture
Description: The Minor in Space Policy, History and Culture, offered through Embry-Riddle’s College of Arts and Sciences, allows students to explore space as a social, political, economic, and cultural phenomenon. This 15-credit minor focuses on the complex nature of human interactions with the space environment, equipping students with a multidisciplinary understanding of space activities. Students will examine space exploration from various angles, including its historical context, ethical implications, and global governance frameworks. The curriculum covers topics such as international space law, space security, commercial space ventures, and the cultural impact of space on society. Students will learn about space history, policy, law, culture, and ethics. They will analyze historical and contemporary issues in space policy, evaluate the geopolitical and socioeconomic impacts of space activities, develop critical thinking skills to address complex challenges in space governance, and engage in interdisciplinary research on space-related topics. This minor prepares students for roles in space advocacy, diplomacy, policy analysis, and related fields, enhancing career prospects in government agencies (like NASA, NOAA, Department of State), aerospace companies, think tanks, non-profit organizations, and international organizations (like the United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs). It complements a wide range of majors, including aerospace engineering, aeronautical science, homeland security, and global security and intelligence studies.

The Minor in Space Studies program at Embry-Riddle is designed for students seeking to broaden their knowledge in space-related disciplines. This program offers a unique interdisciplinary approach, drawing from various fields such as astronomy, engineering, space law, and policy. Students will explore topics like spacecraft design, orbital mechanics, space exploration, and the legal and ethical aspects of space utilization. This minor is ideal for those passionate about space and looking to enhance their primary degree with specialized expertise, preparing them for careers in the growing space industry or further academic pursuits.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $1,365 (value of one 3-credit course for specific grants like the Loyalty Grant or Graduation Grant)
ScholarshipType: Grants based on affiliation (family, alumni) and academic progress

ProgramName: Minor in Supply Chain Management in Aviation and Aerospace
Department: David B. O'Maley College of Business
Description: The Supply Chain Management in Aviation and Aerospace minor prepares students to understand and integrate current supply chain technologies and management systems in the aviation and aerospace industry. Students will gain knowledge in areas such as procurement and sourcing, logistics and distribution, quality control, operations management, and supply chain analytics. The minor complements various degree programs by providing a specialized understanding of supply chain principles critical to the aviation and aerospace sector, enhancing graduates' competitiveness in a rapidly evolving global market.

Requirements: The Minor in Systems Engineering is open to all degree-seeking students at the Daytona Beach and Prescott campuses.
Description: Systems Engineering is an interdisciplinary field of engineering and engineering management that focuses on how to design and manage complex systems over their life cycles. As a systems engineer, you learn to oversee the complete life cycle of projects and products, from concept to production, operation, and ultimately, disposal. You will learn to integrate the knowledge of all technical disciplines, including software, hardware, and human-factors engineering, into a coherent whole. Systems engineers work with various industries, including aerospace, defense, energy, healthcare, and transportation, and are responsible for ensuring that all components of a project or product work together seamlessly. The Systems Engineering Minor is an excellent option for any student interested in learning about the interdisciplinary aspects of designing, developing, and managing complex systems over their life cycles. This minor helps prepare students for successful careers in various industries, including aerospace, defense, energy, healthcare, and transportation.

Requirements:
This minor prepares students from any major for intelligence or counterintelligence careers in government or the private sector. The required courses examine the structure and function of the U.S. Intelligence Community and provide an overview of the four major intelligence disciplines: collection, analysis, counterintelligence, and covert action. Students then have some flexibility to choose from courses focusing on specific regions or issues.

SIS 325: Strategic Intelligence and National Security Policymaking
SIS 330: Special Operations in National Security

SIS 425: Disinformation & Influence Operations
Description: The Technical Intelligence minor prepares students to analyze technical data and synthesize intelligence information from publicly available and classified sources. Students learn the analytical process for identifying, collecting, exploiting, and disseminating technical intelligence about foreign weapons and space systems. The interdisciplinary curriculum focuses on analyzing technical intelligence data with applications to national security and commercial applications. The minor provides a multi-domain analytical framework that focuses on advanced technologies such as cyber, artificial intelligence, unmanned and autonomous systems, hypersonics, and space systems. Students will learn the collection and analytical tradecraft required to support the intelligence community, federal law enforcement, and national security agencies.

The minor in Technical Management provides the business management expertise necessary to effectively manage engineering and technology-oriented programs and projects. Students will gain an understanding of principles such as organizational behavior, financial management, marketing, and the legal and ethical issues related to operating a business in a global environment. This minor is an excellent complement to technical and engineering degrees, providing students with the skills needed to lead teams and manage projects effectively within a technical field.

Terrorism is a serious threat to national and international security. With the Minor in Terrorism Studies program, you will develop an understanding of the historical, political, and cultural factors associated with terrorism and counterterrorism. You will also learn about the policies and strategies for combating terrorism. This minor is open to all students at Embry-Riddle’s Prescott and Worldwide Campuses.

ProgramName: Minor in Uncrewed Aircraft Systems Applications
Requirements: The minor in Uncrewed Aircraft Systems Applications is open to all degree-seeking students.
Description: Embry-Riddle’s Uncrewed Aircraft Systems Applications minor focuses on the practical application of UAS and their integration into various operations. From basic UAS operations to advanced remote sensing technologies, students will learn to operate UAS in a safe and legal manner while gaining an understanding of the impact of UAS on society. This interdisciplinary minor allows students to apply these technologies to their primary field of study, enhancing their marketability and giving them a competitive edge.

ProgramName: Minor in Uncrewed Aircraft Systems (UAS) in Public Safety
Description: As UAS technology continues to evolve, so does the demand for qualified operators within various public safety organizations. From law enforcement to search and rescue, UAS are becoming indispensable tools for enhancing situational awareness, improving response times, and increasing overall effectiveness. Embry-Riddle’s Uncrewed Aircraft Systems (UAS) in Public Safety Minor provides students with the knowledge and skills necessary to effectively integrate UAS into public safety operations. Whether you’re pursuing a career in law enforcement, emergency management, or firefighting, this minor will provide you with a competitive edge and prepare you for a rewarding career in an increasingly important field. The curriculum covers a range of topics, including UAS operations, regulations, data analysis, and ethical considerations specific to public safety applications. Students will gain hands-on experience with UAS platforms and software, developing the practical skills needed to deploy and operate UAS safely and efficiently in real-world scenarios.
